messageBody:
On Wednesday 14 July 2004 22:05, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> I always throw Exception from tests, because I /know/ (one of the rare
> times I know something) that I want to let JUnit catch any unexpected
> exceptions.

I don't like that throws Exception, even not for Tests.
I can not exactly say why, but it is something along these lines: The
tests drive development. They are the first users of the production code
and if they are hard to write, other production code that uses the code
under test will also be hard to write. Development includes thrown
exception types (throw specifications). If I write throws Exception at
each unit test, I may hide a cumbersome exception specification in the
code under test -- in production code I don't want to have throws
Exception attached to every method.
In short terms: I write no throws to my tests, unless the compiler
complain, and the more often I have to do that, the more often I think
about my throw specifications.

Robert
